revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.6)
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=January 2013}}{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}}}} {{Infobox Military Conflict| conflict=Battle of Kroppenhof| partof=the [[Polish–Swedish War (1621–1625)]]| date=November 28, 1621| place=[[Lobes ezers|Kroppenhof]], [[Livonia]] ([[Latvia]])| result=Polish–Lithuanian victory| combatant1=[[File:Herb Rzeczypospolitej Obojga Narodow.svg|15px]] [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]]| combatant2=[[Image:Naval Ensign of Sweden.svg|23px]] [[Swedish Empire]]| commander1=[[Image:Slepowron.svg|18px]] [[Aleksander Gosiewski]]| commander2=[[Samuel Cockburn (mercenary leader)|Samuel Cockburn]]| strength1=500-600 men| strength2=850 men| casualties1=very few| casualties2=280 killed
7 banners| }} {{Campaignbox Polish–Swedish War (1621–1625)}} The '''Battle of Kroppenhof''' was fought during the [[Polish–Swedish War (1621–1625)]], between [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] and the [[Swedish Empire]] in November 28, 1621. Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth forces under the command of [[Aleksander Gosiewski]] defeated the Swedish forces commanded by [[Samuel Cockburn (mercenary leader)|Samuel Cockburn]]. ==References== *http://www.radoslawsikora.republika.pl/materialy/kropimojza.pdf{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Polish) *Jan Kunowski, Ekspedycja Inflantska 1621 Roku, w opracowaniu Wojciecha Walczaka i Karola Łopateckiego, Białystok 2007 *Sveriges krig 1611-1632, Bd II „Polska Kriget” Appendix II, Stockholm 1936 *Barkman Bertil C., Lundkvist Sven, Kungl. Svea Livgardes historia III:1, Stockholm 1936 {{coord missing|Latvia}} [[Category:Battles involving Poland|Kroppenhof 1621]] [[Category:Battles involving Sweden|Kroppenhof 1621]] [[Category:Battles involving the Grand Duchy of Lithuania|Kroppenhof 1621]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1621|Kroppenhof]] [[Category:1621 in Europe]] [[Category:Duchy of Livonia]] [[Category:17th century in Latvia]] [[Category:History of Poland (1569–1795)]]
